assignments.assignment_description: 수업 중 제시되는  조별요약 과제 올리기
94-98쪽 지문을 읽고 8가지 지침에 따라 형식적으로 요약하시오.
1,2차 개별 요약 과제를 하나의 파일에 담아 제출하기  바랍니다.

개별논평 과제 두 편(장기기증, 유리천장)을 하나의 파일에 담아 제출하기 바랍니다.

작성 기한은 다음 주 화요일 까지입니다.

 유의사항: 형식적 요약은 8가지 지침에 따라, 형식적 논평은 5가지 지침에 따라 작성하기 바랍니다. 

﻿

희망하는 '개별 에세이 주제'를  2-3가지를 우선순위를 정해 제출하시오.

  주제 제시할 때 에세이 유형도 밝히기 바랍니다. 

예) 1순위:  적극적 안락사를 법적으로 허용해야 하는가?(찬반형 에세이)

﻿

에세이 면담을 위해 에세이 프로포절 및 에세이 초고(서론, 결론)를 제출하기 바랍니다.

에세이 프로포절은 필수이고, 초고는 선택 사항입니다. 

13주차 면담 학생들은 마감날짜(5월 17일 월요일 오전 10시까지)를 준수하기 바랍니다.

14주차 면담  학생들은  5월 19일 수요일 오전 10시까지 제출 가능합니다.

﻿

에세이 배점은 25점으로 설정되어 있으나 변경될 수 있습니다.

﻿

이번 학기  강의 소개 및 진행 방식 , 강의 목표, 강의 성격에 대한 참고용으로 올립니다.

﻿

﻿

비판적 사고와 학술적 글쓰기의 연관, 관련 예제 풀이

﻿

3월 2일자 강의녹화영상이 품질이 좋지 않아서, 오늘자 다른 분반 강의녹화영상을 올립니다.

주요 수업 내용은 동일하니 별 문제는 없습니다. ﻿

﻿

﻿

10주차 강의(2)

﻿11주차 강의(1)

﻿

에세이 프로포절

assignments.assignment_description:
2주차 과제로 첨부파일 확인하고 개인창의성양상 테스트 진행 후 결과 화면을 캡처하여 제출하시길 바랍니다.

제출기한은 9월 16일 (목) 23:59 까지입니다.

2-3-창의적융합디자인-PCMT-과제.pdf

첨부파일은 창의적융합디자인 개인과제 1입니다.

개인과제 1은 온라인/오프라인 검색 후 2020년 한 해동안의 10대 히트상품을 나열하고 이에 대하여 간단한 설명과 분석을 5쪽으로 정리하는 것입니다. 

1주차의 제품, 제품개발과정 및 디자인 프로세스에 대한 내용을 참고로 하여 본인이 생각하는 10대 상품(제품, 서비스, 콘텐츠 등 포함)에 대한 분석 리포트입니다. 

이 때 인터넷 등에 있는 히트상품 리스트를 참고해도 되는데 학생이라는 본인의 상황을 고려한 10대 상품을 리스트해주세요. 예를 들어 무슨 부동산 상품 같은 학생과는 거리가 먼 히트상품 분석은 지양해주시기 바랍니다. 

또한 다른 전문가가 선택한 10대 상품을 언급해도 되지만 본인이 생각하는 상품을 포함해도 됩니다. 

제출기한은 10/4(월)까지입니다.

assignments.assignment_name: 창의적 문제해결 프로젝트 발표 동영상 제출
assignments.assignment_description:
창의적 문제해결 프로젝트 발표 동영상 제출란입니다.

11주차 사전강의 교안을 참고하여 발표 동영상을 제작하시길 바랍니다.

팀별로 대표학생 1명이 제출하면 되고, 제출 기한은 11/18 목요일 11:59 pm 까지 입니다.

동영상 분량은 7분 이내의 MP4 파일로 제작하고 모든 팀원이 발표에 참여해야 합니다.

제출 기한 이후에 실수로 다른 동영상을 제출했다, 동영상 품질이 낮아 다시 제출하고 싶다 등의 내용으로 문의하는 것에 대해서는 허용하지 않을 예정이니
이러한 실수가 발생하지 않도록 제출 시 동영상 파일을 꼼꼼하게 체크하여 제출하시길 바랍니다.

첨부1-창의적문제해결프로젝트_학생평가지-1.xlsx

본인 팀을 제외한 다른 팀의 창의적 문제해결 프로젝트 발표 영상을 시청한 후 학생 평가를 진행하시길 바랍니다.

팀 내에서 상의하여 진행하는 것이 아닌 개인적으로 평가하는 과제입니다.

제출 기한은 11월 24일 수요일입니다.

첨부2-창의적문제해결프로젝트_동료평가지-1.xlsx

창의적 문제해결 프로젝트 수행 기간 중 팀 내에서 본인을 제외한 다른 모든 팀원의 기여도를 평가합니다.

팀원 간 상의하여 평가하는 것이 아닌 개인적으로 팀 내의 기여도를 평가하여 제출하시길 바랍니다.

학생평가와 마찬가지로 제출 기한은 11월 24일 수요일까지 입니다.

13주차 수업시간에 공지했던 바와 같이 팀별로 Happy smile gate 프로토타입 최종 발표 동영상 제작이 진행되고 있는 것으로 알고 있습니다.

현재 제작하고 있는 동영상은 12월 9일 (목요일) 23:59까지 제출하시면 됩니다.

동영상 구성은 디자인 과정 (브레인스토밍, 상세디자인, 최종솔루션 스케치 등) 3~4분 + 프로토타입 설명 3~4분으로 진행되며 동영상의 총 분량은 7분 이내 입니다.

모든 학생이 나누어서 발표해야하고 자세한 사항은 15주차 강의안을 확인하시길 바랍니다.

(오해의 소지가 있어서 추가로 설명드립니다.
모든 학생이 발표에 참여해야 한다는 것은 발표자 한명을 뽑아도 되고 모든 학생이 나누어 발표를 해도 되지만,
무임승차 하는 팀원이 없도록 모든 팀원이 발표 동영상 제작에 적극적으로 참여해야 한다는 의미로 해석하시면 될 것 같습니다.)

파일명은 Happy smile gate_00팀.mp4 로 저장하여 제출하시길 바랍니다.

assignments.assignment_name: W01-1 Goorm Howto and WA explained

assignments.assignment_description:
The demonstrative presentation is in Week 5. You will make a 10-minute presentation in pairs. (There may occasionally be a group of three.) These groups have been assigned randomly. Please contact your partner to decide what you will present, and how you will work. The first five groups (Groups 1–5) will present during the first lesson in Week 5, and the others (Groups 6–10) will present during the second lesson. The earlier students will do their second presentation later, and vice-versa.

All presentation lessons will be live-streamed on Webex. Every student must attend each session so that all presenters have a sizeable audience. You will need a webcam and a microphone, and you will need to install Webex. Everyone should keep your camera on at all times so the presenters feel the presence of the audience. If you turn your camera off, you will be considered absent from class. Our Webex room is at https://skku-ict.webex.com/meet/jpbarrass (Meeting room 573 469 208). If you are able, you should stand up. This is so that we can see your body language the same way that we can see body language when people present offline. All students are encouraged to ask questions after presentations.

Since you cannot be together physically, I recommend that one student take the first half of the presentation, and the other student do the second half. Otherwise, transitions between partners could become very confusing. You should familiarise yourselves with how to show your PowerPoint file on Webex.

You must demonstrate something. This means that you must show us a process. A process is something that occurs in stages that have a fixed order. (It is not possible to change the order of the steps.) Since processes rarely have three convenient stages, the Rule of Three does not apply in this presentation. You may instruct the audience on how to do something, or you may explain how something happens. Since some groups may select the same topic, you should send me a message on iCampus so I can approve your topic. If your topic duplicates another group's, or if your topic is not a process, I will reject it.

As mentioned above, the presentation should take ten minutes. If your presentation takes 9–11 minutes, you will get full points. If it is under 9 minutes or over 11, you will lose one point. You will lose one further point for each extra minute. If you go over the time limit, and your points for timing reduce to zero, I will stop your presentation, and you will lose the points available for anything that you have not completed. This is so that the next pair have sufficient time for their presentation.

Your speech will be graded with the score sheet shown below. If you can't see a score sheet below, access this assignment via Assignments in the main menu.

Please upload your PowerPoint file here before your presentation so I can check it later in case of any confusion over scores.

The informative presentation is in the four lessons of Weeks 9 and 10. It will be done in larger groups (typically five people). There will only be one presentation on each day. You will make a 50-minute presentation, and each person should speak for an approximately equal time (average 10 minutes). You will present with different people from your demonstrative presentation partner, and you will present in reverse order to the demonstrative presentation. Please contact your partners to decide what you will present, and how you will work.

All presentation lessons will be live-streamed on Webex. Every student must attend each session so that all presenters have a sizeable audience. You will need a webcam and a microphone, and you will need to install Webex. Everyone should keep your camera on at all times so the presenters feel the presence of the audience. If you turn your camera off, you will be considered absent from class. You will need a webcam and a microphone, and you will need to install Webex. Our Webex room is at https://skku-ict.webex.com/meet/jpbarrass (Meeting room 573 469 208). If you are able, you should stand up. This is so that we can see your body language the same way that we can see body language when people present offline. All students are encouraged to ask questions after presentations.

Since you cannot be together physically, I recommend that one student take the first part of the presentation, ﻿the second student do next part, and so on. Otherwise, transitions between partners could become very confusing. You should familiarise yourselves with how to show your PowerPoint file on Webex.

As mentioned above, the presentation should take 50 minutes. If your presentation takes 47–53 minutes, you will get full points. If it is under 47 minutes or over 53, you will lose one point. You will lose one further point for each extra three minutes. If you go over the time limit, and your points for timing reduce to zero, I will stop your presentation, and you will lose the points available for anything that you have not completed.

Your speech will be graded with the score sheet shown below. If you can't see a score sheet below, access this assignment via Assignments in the main menu.

Please upload your PowerPoint file here before your presentation so I can check it later in case of any confusion over scores.

The persuasive presentation is in the four lessons of Weeks 14 and 15. It will be done individually. You will make a 10-minute presentation. You will present in random order.

All presentation lessons will be live-streamed on Webex. Every student must attend each session so that all presenters have a sizeable audience. You will need a webcam and a microphone, and you will need to install Webex. Everyone should keep your camera on at all times so the presenters feel the presence of the audience. If you turn your camera off, you will be considered absent from class. You will need a webcam and a microphone, and you will need to install Webex. Our Webex room is at https://skku-ict.webex.com/meet/jpbarrass (Meeting room 573 469 208). If you are able, you should stand up. This is so that we can see your body language the same way that we can see body language when people present offline. All students are encouraged to ask questions after presentations.

You should familiarise yourself with how to show your PowerPoint file on Webex.

You must persuade your audience of something. Since some students may select the same topic, you should send me a message on iCampus so I can approve your topic. If your topic duplicates another student's, or if your topic is not persuasive, I will reject it.

As mentioned above, the presentation should take 10 minutes. If your presentation takes 9–11 minutes, you will get full points. If it is under 9 minutes or over 11, you will lose one point. You will lose one further point for each extra minute. If you go over the time limit, and your points for timing reduce to zero, I will stop your presentation, and you will lose the points available for anything that you have not completed. This is so that the next people have sufficient time for their presentations.

Your speech will be graded with the score sheet shown below. If you can't see a score sheet below, access this assignment via Assignments in the main menu.

For this assignment, you should upload two files here before your presentation: your PowerPoint file and a photo of your cue cards.

Since we are online this week, we don't have the opportunity to meet each other in the classroom. We should therefore introduce ourselves here instead. Please don't only write 'My name is ___, I'm ___ years old, and I'm from ___." Instead, try to tell us something interesting about you. Please also reply to other students' posts, and make it like a real chat. I hope we can meet soon in the classroom, but in the meantime it'll be nice to 'meet' you here.

Choose one of the following topics, and prepare a hook.

  • Types of monkey
  • Crossfit
  • Abolishing homework
  • Social media
  • The Olympic Games
  • Buying a house
  • Brewing beer
  • Growing herbs
  • Yoga

I have made this as a discussion so you can see each other's ideas. Let's learn from each other. Please comment on each other's ideas, too.

Our book (Page 35) suggests four methods of concluding memorably:

  • making a suggestion,
  • giving a warning (negative prediction),
  • making a (positive) prediction, and
  • making a call to action.

Write memorable ends for the presentation topics on Page 37. Take turns to write these. The first person to comment should write a suggestion for My University Life. The second person should write a (positive) prediction for My University Life. Continue down the page till all eight are complete. The ninth person should return to the top of the page (a suggestion for My University Life), and write a different example.

Use the examples on Page 36 to help you if you wish. Please comment on each other's work. Thanks.

Pages 25–27 explain transition sentences. These are the cohesion that binds supporting points together. Please write a transition for the topics on Page 28. Number 1 is an example. This leads from food in Paris to sights in Paris. The connecting topic is Paris, and the transition moves from food to sights. This example uses the past and future (not the past and a rhetorical question). Note that the grammatical tense isn't really important here: the time of the actions is more important.

In this activity, please write one transition. The first person to comment should write a past/future transition for Number 1. The second person should write a past/future transition for Number 2, and so on. When someone has written a past/future transition for Number 10, the next (eleventh) person should write a past/question transition for Number 1, the twelfth person should write a past/question transition for Number 2, and so on.

Please comment on each other's work. Thanks.

What kind og stories could embellish presentations about the following topics?

  1. Violent crime
  2. Friendship
  3. Love
  4. Pain
  5. Fitness
  6. Backing up files
  7. Loss
  8. Dinner

Please write about only one topic in one post. Write by replying in the appropriate thread, please. Do not write, for example, about fitness stories in the friendship thread. Thanks.

Look at the following list of topics, and select one.

  1. You should eat less meat.
  2. You should live abroad.
  3. You should never get married.
  4. You should get married.
  5. You should buy me some nice food.

Do not tell us your chosen topic.

Our integrated structure includes three new features: Need, Visualise, and Action. Plan these three sections for your chosen topic. Explain these three features. Do not plan or explain anything else. I repeat: do not tell us which topic you have selected.

Other students should then reply, guessing which topic you selected. Please reply to these students.

Let's consider some advanced techniques of persuasion in this ungraded optional assignment. Do not submit anything here.

1. Limiting options

Barry Schwartz talks in this 20-minute video about how limiting options is a useful persuasive technique.

2. Loss aversion

People hate losing things more than they like getting things. Consider how children reacts when their balloons burst. You would benefit by telling the audience what they will lose if they reject your opinion.

3. Make your product expensive

People perceive expensive products as more valuable, so they want them more. What should people lose in order to accept your opinion?

4. Intensity

Using strong language (but not swearing) suggests passion. Some people worry that they will appear foolish, but Steve Jobs—often considered a great speaker—often used the word insane.

5. Scarcity

The sale ends today! Only five items left! Webinar attendance is capped at 100! These are common sales techniques. Scarce goods are perceived as more valuable.

6. Leave

Tell the wrong people to leave in order to keep the right people. If you say whom you are not targeting, those who like your opinion will like it even more.

7. Mystery

People are fascinated by mysterious things like cults, North Korea, and so on. By advertising with terms such as “Never-before revealed secrets,” “Undisclosed guest,” “Highly classified information,” and “Legally prevented from releasing”, you can increase this mystery.

8. Philanthropy

People feel good when they give to others, but people rarely do this. Automate this process for your audience. For every pair of shoes purchased, another pair is given to a child in poverty.

Here are four videos of presentations that use storytelling. Please watch them, and consider how you may be able to use storytelling in your presentation. I have no idea why, but the spacing between these videos is very strange in this assignment. I can't fix it, so please just scroll down through the blank spaces. There is nothing to submit for this assignment.

1. This 15-minute presentation uses a personal story. Warning: this video discusses domestic violence.

2. This one tells a simple story interspersed with some light humour.
3. This story involves suspense.
4. This presenter tells a story, but he also shows a story. He does this with humour, too.
This is the computerised voice that I mentioned in the Voice video. I can only set this up as an assignment, but you don't have to submit anything!
This is our PowerPoint file.

All presentations need cited evidence to support them. Citations show that your statements are validated by others' work, so you gain ethos and logos by using them.

Nowadays no one writes in-text citations or reference lists manually: all academics use reference management software. There are many programs that can help, but I'll introduce only one: Mendeley. I've chosen Mendeley, not because it's better than others, but because it's one of the most popular programs, it's the one that I use (so I can help you), and it's free. I'm not advertising the product, though!

Mendeley is owned by Elsevier, a major academic publisher. Signing up means that you would be giving Elsevier your name and email address. If you aren't comfortable with that, then please find another way to manage references.

If you sign up, you should download the program, and log in. You can import your resources here. You should also install the MS Word plugin (in the menu). Then, in Word (but not in Word 365), you can insert citations using Mendeley Cite-O-Matic in the References tab. You can also select whatever style you wish here. For example, engineers typically use IEEE style. These in-text citations often appear at the bottom of relevant PowerPoint slides. When you have all of your citations, click Insert bibliography, and the full reference list will be produced. This should be put on the last slide.

For further information regarding Mendeley, I'm sharing a lesson I recorded previous for my English Writing class. The beginning is similar to what we covered in our class, as plagiarism is important in both writing and presenting. Please watch this video from 34:18 onwards to see the part about Mendeley. This is not compulsory viewing: it does not count towards attendance.

If you have any questions regarding references, please let me know.﻿

In this lesson we are looking at skills that advertisers or marketers use to control us. To examine this, we will see five videos by a British psychologist and showman called Derren Brown. In the first video, there will be a lot of physical action and some language. In the second, there's more language and a little less physical action, though it still depends a lot on physical action. In the third there's a dominance of language but still some physical action, and in the fourth it's all about language. The last video is somewhat separate.

Video 1

Derren Brown is rather famous in the U.K. for controlling people's minds, so he sometimes works in the U.S., where his language tricks still work, but where people don't run away from him! In this video, he's in Las Vegas, talking with some local people in a nightclub. Notice which hand he holds up and which shoulder he touches. This is important for this skill to work.

As you saw in this video, through this apparently simple trick, the woman's perception of her surroundings changed. She associated certainty with one side of her body, and uncertainty with the other. We aren't aiming for this kind of thing in our presentations, of course, but this demonstrates that people attach emotional states to locations. You can consider this when you're preparing your presentations. You could put positive things on one side of your PowerPoint slides, and negative things on the other side, for example. In offline presentations you could then stand by the positive side so the audience associates you with positive feelings. Remember that every salesperson is selling themselves—trying to make the audience like them—and persuasion is similar to selling things. In an online presentation, you could point to the positive side more, but it's perhaps more difficult to apply this skill online.

Video 2

Here, Derren Brown is in Blackpool in north-west England. He asks for directions to the Pleasure Beach—a terrible name for Blackpool's fairground on a beach. Watch the video to see how he steals from someone.

This does not work on everyone; it tends to work on about one in three people, and on people who are not currently in an alert state. He begins by asking a typical question about directions. Then, to test whether this person will naturally follow, he steps away from him. The man does indeed follow, so he immediately procedes with the next question: "You don't mind me asking you, do you?" Of course no one minds being asked for directions, but this sets up the following statement: 'You're happy to give that to me.' This is a slightly unusual thing to say in this situation, but if someone isn't especially alert, they'll just accept this phrase, and move on in the conversation. Then the important moment happens: they shake hands. This is a normal everyday interaction, so we all do it automatically without really thinking about controlling our muscles. When something typically automatic is suddenly different, however, this confuses the mind. Note that Derren Brown transferred the man's hand into his other (left) hand. This is peculiar, and this confusion was enhanced by his handing his water bottle to him. Then, in this confused state, the other person was 'happy to give that to [him]'. Note that once he had taken the man's belongings, Derren Brown thanked him, and he said 'Thank you; you're fine.' This is another unusual thing to say, and then a few seconds later he was fine. This does not explain how he took his belongings a second time, though. This was possible because he asked the person to hold his bottle again. The bottle is known psychologically as an anchor. Every time this person holds this bottle, their mind will return to the same state, and they will be 'happy to give that'.

We aren't going to steal from our audience, of course, but we can learn something from this: anchoring. The most common anchor is the heart. In almost all cultures, we associate emotion with the heart. Therefore, if you place your hand over your heart when you say positive things, your audience will associate those positive emotions with you, and they will like you more. Conversely, if you place your hand over your heart when you say negative things, the opposite will happen, so don't do that!

Video 3

This video is filmed on the London Underground. Everyone is on a train, so everyone is thinking about trains. Derren Brown approaches passengers, and he appears to be talking about trains, but he isn't. Try to pay attention to which words give him control over their minds here.

Note how he said 'trains... of thought'. A train of thought is a series of related thoughts or ideas. We all sometimes lose track of our train of thought. (Sometimes Thought A leads to Thought B, and we need to get to C, but we start thinking about X, Y, and Z, and then we struggle to get back to B so we can move on to C.) The first passenger really thinks he's still talking about trains, but he isn't really, so this confuses the passenger somewhat. The example with the second passenger is perhaps clearer, though. In both cases, note that he asked 'What stop are you getting off at?' He used the word stop instead of station because stop has a useful alternative meaning. With the second passenger, he said 'What stop—thinking about it now—are you getting off at?' This includes the phrase 'Stop thinking about it.', and he grouped these words together with some hand motion. This combined with their confused states gave him temporary control over their memory.

Again, we aren't aiming to do this with our audience, but we can see that word choice is important. Consider hair dye. Advertisements rarely use the term hair dye, instead preferring hair colour because dye sounds the same as die, and that has very negative connotations. Consider the words that you will use in your presentations. Do any have alternative negative meanings? Try to change these to other words with more positive alternative connotations. Consider the following example from someone selling board markers. 'A lot of people in many jobs use board markers. I'm sure that you will, like this one.' This includes 'You will like this.', and the other meaning of like is very useful here. This can have a small but measureable effect.

Video 4

In this video, Derren Brown 'buys' things from people in New York using blank paper instead of money. Watch the video and listen to his words, considering how he does it.

Perhaps the simplest example is the first one in the fish shop. He wants to buy three fillets of sole. When walking to the counter, he starts a simple light chat to distract the shopkeeper's mind from the transaction. Since he has an English accent, he is obviously not from New York, so he mentions that he was scared about taking the subway, but someone told him 'It's fine. Take it; it's fine.' Take has another meaning, so the shopkeeper took the money, and it was fine. He then tried this with a person at a hot dog stand, but it failed. Take has another meaning—to take medicine—but this person is likely much more alert as the hot dog stand is on the street; people working in such locations tend to be less comfortable, and very aware of their surroundings. We, of course, are not going to steal from our audience, but we can see from this that word choice really is very powerful.

Video 5

In this video, Derren Brown invites two advertisers to perform a task that they don't know about. Watch the video, and consider how it was done.

In this case, the trick was performed with subliminal messaging. We all see and hear things all the time, but we don't always notice them consciously. Subconsciously, however, we notice a lot, and we remember these things, so we feel familiar with products that we think we don't know. Consider designated driver services in Korea. If you drink alcohol, and you need someone to drive your car, you should call a number, and someone will come and drive you home for a fee. Do you know any telephone numbers for these services? Which number would you dial? We'll come back to this later. Here, the advertisers did not know that the production team had planted subliminal messages along their journey, and even though they work in advertising (so they know these tricks), it still worked on them.

My point here is that your audience will pay more attention than they or you often realise. What they see and hear really matters. Your visual aids are therefore extremely important. Pay close attention to making them effective.

I hope that these videos demonstrated some psychological skills in a somewhat fun way. Note that there's nothing to submit here, but there's a quiz for you to take after this.

우리 연구실에서 진행 중인 연구를 소개하는 영상을 공유합니다.

우리 연구실은 데이터를 기반으로 하여 새로운 소재를 디자인하는 연구를 합니다. 주로 실험 데이터를 빠르게 얻는 기법을 이용하고, 머신러닝으로 분석하여 새로운 소재의 물성을 예측하고, 이 과정을 통해 물성이 뛰어난 새로운 소재를 개발하는 연구를 합니다.

반도체 배선재료, 초내열합금, 비정질합금 등 다양한 차세대 소재를 이 기법을 활용하여 개발 중입니다. 자세한 내용은 본 영상과 우리 연구실 홈페이지를 통해 확인 가능합니다. ﻿(https://www.dleelab.org)

*﻿열류전지-->연료전지

(오타 정정합니다)﻿

<일반 학생의 기말시험 문제는 아래 주제와 관련 없음>

※ PDF로 변환하여 제출하시기 바랍니다.

 

[1] 오늘날 한국 국회의원 선거제도를 대표성과 통치성 차원에서 평가하고, 제도적 차원의 개선방안을 제시하시오. (35점)

      <분량> 공백포함 2000자 이내 (분량 초과 시 감점)

      <평가기준>

         1 . 오늘날 한국 국회의원 선거제도를 바르게 기술하였는가? (10점)

         2. 민주주의에 있어 대표성과 통치성의 의미를 이해하고, 평가가 논리적인가? (10점)

         3. 제시한 개선방안이 합리적이고 설득력 있는가? (10점)

         4. 강의에서 학습한 내용을 제대로 이해하고, 적절하게 활용하는가? (5점)

 

[2] 좋은 정치는 민주주의를 통해서만 성취될 수 있다고 생각하는가? 동의하거나 동의하지 않는 이유는 무엇인가? (25점)

      <분량> 공백포함 1500자 이내 (분량 초과 시 감점)

      <평가기준>

         1. 좋은 정치와 민주주의를 적절하게 규정하고 있는가? (10점)

         2. 근거 제시에 있어 논리성과 설득력을 갖추었는가? (10점)

         3. 강의에서 학습한 내용을 제대로 이해하고, 적절하게 활용하는가? (5점)

     

본 강의와 같은 대규모 온라인 교양 과목의 평가는 상대평가로 이루어지는데,  A등급 50% 이내, A+B등급 90% 이내로 평가 비율이 정해져 있습니다. 그리고 군인학생 평가는 별도 그룹으로 편성되어 군인들끼리 평가됩니다. 중간 과제 평가 결과 군인학생들의 과제가 전반적으로 우수했고, 일반학생 그룹과 달리 과제 미제출자도 거의 없었습니다. 따라서 안타깝지만 적은 점수 차로도 최종 평가가 갈릴 수도 있다는 점을 미리 알려드립니다.

과거 비민주적 제도였던 선거가 오늘날 민주적 제도로 간주되게 된 역사적 과정을 기술하시오.

※ 평가 기준

  • 강의 이해도: 50% (강의 내용을 적절하게 활용하였는가?)
  • 설득력: 30% (근거와 예시를 잘 제시하였는가?)
  • 논리성: 20% (논의 전개 방식이 논리적인가?)

※ pdf로 업로드(한글, 워드 상관없음) / 전공, 학번, 이름 기입 / 글자크기 11, 기본 줄간격(한글 160, 워드 1.08), 2페이지 이내로 작성

assignments.assignment_description:
2024년 기계재료 연습문제

 

 

다음 각 경우에 경도를 구하세요.

 

 

  1. AISI 1020강(SM20C)을 g 영역으로 가열한 후에 평형 냉각을 하였다.

 

 

 

  1. AISI 1020강(SM20C)을 g 영역으로 가열한 후에 annealing을 하였다.

 

 

 

  1. AISI 1020강(SM20C)을 g 영역으로 가열한 후에 공기 중에서 냉각하였다.

 

 

 

  1. AISI 1020강(SM20C)을 g 영역으로 가열한 후에 기름에서 냉각하였다.

 

 

 

  1. AISI 1020강(SM20C)을 g 영역으로 가열한 후에 물에서 Quenching 하였다.

 

 

 

  1. AISI 1040강(SM40C)을 g 영역으로 가열한 후에 공기 중에서 냉각하였다.

 

 

 

  1. AISI 1040강을 g 영역으로 가열한 후에 기름에서 Quenching 하였다.

 

 

 

  1. AISI 1040강(SM40C)을 g 영역으로 가열한 후에 물에서 Quenching 하였다.

 

 

 

  1. (합금강) AISI 4340강을 g 영역으로 가열한 후에 공기 중에서 냉각하였다.

 

 

 

  1. AISI 4340강을 g 영역으로 가열한 후에 기름에서 Quenching 하였다.

 

 

 

  1. 200 MPa의 경도를 얻기 위해서 어떤 steel을 어떻게 냉각해야 하는가?

첨부 문서를 보고, 빈 칸을 채우세요.

CH 3 Miller Index.pptx

 

중간시험은 22일 (월) 수업시간에 (10시 30분) 강의실이 아닌 301호에서 봅니다.

주의사항: 실습 결과물 이미지까지 노트북 파일 내에 포함되어 저장되어있는지 확인하고 제출해주세요. 일반적인 방법으로 저장하면, 실습 결과물 이미지까지 저장됩니다.

실습과제 01은 구글 colab에서 수행하는 과제입니다.

첨부된 노트북 파일(2024_AI_BU_01.ipynb)을 보시면
카페에서 카페 운영을 분석하며, 일일 매출과 그날의 총 방문객 수 사이의 관계를 분석하고자 합니다.
주어진 데이터는 특정 일자에 대한 방문객 수(x)와 그날의 총 매출(y)입니다.

실행된 결과 화면을 살펴보면 w, b가 매우 큰 음수 값으로, gradient exploding 경향을 보이고 있습니다.

알맞은 w, b 값을 찾을 수 있도록 두 개의 파라미터 값을 적절히 설정하여 수정한 뒤 결과값을 출력하고, 수정한 부분에 직접 설명을 주석으로 적어 제출하세요.

두 개의 파라미터 이외에 다른 부분은 절대 수정하지 마세요.


[루브릭]
1점 - 위 지시 사항을 만족하여 기간 내에 파일을 제출한 경우
0점 - 미제출, 지각제출, 학습이 제대로 되지 않는 경우, 2024_AIBU_01.ipynb이 아닌 다른 파일을 제출한 경우
-1점 - 다른 사람의 파일을 그대로 제출한 경우(의심이 되는 코드인 경우 제대로 소명이 안되면 -1점을 드립니다.)

AI기초와활용 기말고사를 볼 때에는 다음 사항을 신중하게 읽어보고 유의하여 응시해주세요.

 

1) 정해진 장소에 오프라인으로 시험에 참석합니다. 시험은 각자 시험을 시작한 15분 후 마칩니다.

2) 시험에 응시할 노트북을 지참합니다. (시험에 응시할 수 있도록 배터리 충전, 전원 확보 등을 반드시 확인합니다.)

3) 아이캠퍼스 시험 응시 중엔 다른 활동(검색, 다른 창 열기 등...)이 금지됩니다. 응시자의 행동이 로그로 수집 되므로 시험 멈춤이 나타나는 경우 올바른 소명이 되지 않으면 기말고사는 0점 처리 됩니다.

4) 실수로 시험 멈춤 상황(or 다른 활동을 한 경우)이 된 경우 손을 들어 감독관을 부르고, 조용히 감독관에게 상황을 설명을 합니다. 감독관이 시험 멈춤 상황과 시간을 기록한 후 시험을 재개합니다.

5) 문제를 풀고 다음 문제로 넘어가면 이전 문제로 돌아갈 수 없습니다.

6) 시험을 마친 후엔 모든 응시생의 시험을 마칠 때까지 자리에 대기합니다.

7) 시험 중 문제와 관련한 문의는 일절 받지 않습니다. 문제가 잘못 된 경우라고 생각이 되어도 일단 주어진 대로 풀이하시면 됩니다. 단, 문제의 그림이나 보기가 보이지 않는 경우는 조용히 손을 들어 시험 감독관에게 이야기 하면 됩니다.

assignments.assignment_name: [테스트]   미래차 부트캠프 고급 : 교과 및 비교과 활동 시간 인정 신청
assignments.assignment_description:
• 신청대상 : 미래차 부트캠프 고급(몰입형, 교과연계형) 이수자
  • 신청내용 : 미래차 부트캠프 고급 과정의 교과 및 비교과 활동 시간 인정 신청
  • 신청방법 : 아이캠퍼스에서 설문 응답 및 증빙서류 제출
  • 신청시기 : 2025년 00월 00일(월) ~ 00월 00일(금)
  • 처리순서 : 비교과 활동 → 아이캠퍼스에서 설문 응답 및 증빙서류 제출 → 해당 활동별 시간 인정 

              예시) 경진대회 참여 → 아이캠퍼스에서 설문 응답 및 증빙서류 제출 → 미래차 부트캠프 고급 과정 비교과 90시간 인정

 

[제출서류]

  • 자율주행캡스톤디자인, 스마트카융합종합설계 : 성적증명서 제출(해당 과목 형광펜으로 표시)
  • 경진대회(회당 90시간 인정) : 참여확인서, 활동보고서 제출
  • 현장실습(과목당 60시간 인정) : 성적증명서 제출(해당 과목 형광펜으로 표시)
  • 학생주도형연구과제(URP/과목당 30시간 인정) : 성적증명서 제출(해당 과목 형광펜으로 표시)
  • 논문(편당 30시간 인정) : 논문, 표지 및 게재증명서(게재예정증명서) 제출
  • 비교과 프로그램(프로그램당 30시간 인정) : 비교과 프로그램 이수증명서 제출(해당 과목 형광펜으로 표시, 중급에서 인정받은 과목 중복 인정 불가)

assignments.assignment_name: [테스트] 미래차 부트캠프 중급 :  비교과 프로그램 공통과목 분야 선택
assignments.assignment_description:
• 신청대상 : 비교과 프로그램 중 공통 과목 이수자
  • 신청내용 : 기 이수한 비교과 프로그램 공통 과목에 대한 분야 선택
  • 신청방법 : 아이캠퍼스에서 설문 작성 후 제출
  • 신청시기 : 2025년 00월 00일(월) ~ 00월 00일(금)
  • 처리순서 : 비교과 프로그램 공통 과목 이수 → 아이캠퍼스에서 설문 작성 후 제출 → 신청 분야 과목으로 이수 처리

      예시) 미래차 SDV 마이크로디그리 신청 → ‘차량용 네트워크’ 이수 → SDV 분야로 선택 → ‘미래차SDV연구(0학점,P/F)’ 과목 이수 처리 됨

     

[ 유의사항 ]

  • 분야 선택 후 변경 불가
  • 미래차 부트캠프 및 미래차 SDV, 전동화, 자율주행 마이크로디그리 신청 분야와 동일하게 신청
